Owning a clear electric kettle is great.  Initially, it's dissolved gasses which range from disinfectant from your local water purification to dissolved oxygen, nitrogen, and carbon dioxide. It is interesting to watch these grow on the bottom of the kettle like inverse raindrops holding on by surface tension. Much of the dissolved gas at the top comes out of solution and forms a fog of micro-bubbles. Most of this dissolved gas rapidly goes away but a some at the bottom hangs on until there is a rolling boil which breaks the surface tension. Once the kettle gets close to a rolling boil… those bubbles are water itself in its gaseous state. Pretty impressive that one liter of water at 99°C can make over 700 litres of water vapour at 101°C.  Who ever came up with making the heating element in the bottom of this kettle semi-circular to use convection to initiate a rotary current, drawing cooler water from the top, thus and evenly mix the water as the kettle boils was rather clever.

So, if you had water from somewhere else, sealed in a container, and then you boiled it, the bubbles would be the air from where the water came from. There is this concept of twice boiling water, where those gases were released the first time, and then the second time, the water can become superheated and dangerous.

Steam. There might be a little dissolved air, but it is mostly steam. At first the bubbles form in direct contact with the pan where the heating element is, and when a bubble breaks loose it immediately encounters cooler water and condenses back to water. But that water is getting hotter both from the condensing steam and from convection from the pan bottom, and as it does the steam bubble last longer, eventually being able to reach the surface to burst open, delivering the steam to the air above the water. As it rises the cooler air again condenses the water into tiny droplets (cloud), which rises in the air convection and then evaporates back into invisible steam in air that doesn’t have 100% humidity.

Water vapour (Steam) in the main. Initially perhaps a little air as the water will have dissolved air (Nitrogen, Oxygen plus other gases that would have been in the air where the water was obtained from). If you watch the boiling the bubbled form where the heat is. As soon as the bubble has enough buoyancy to release it from the heated surface it rises quickly to the surface. Don’t forget that the water itself is swirling around as the hot water also rises to the surface. This is why a strongly boiling pot seems so violent.

Water. Well, technically steam, but that's just water in vapor form. Boiling is the process of water turning to steam at a rapid rate. Since it typically involves water being heated from the bottom, water on the bottom turns into bubbles of water vapor, which then rises to the surface and escapes.
Initially the bubbles are mainly air and with time - when dissolved air gets depleted - it is of water vapour & steam.
If the water is truly boiling, the bubbles are water converted to steam. If it is not quite boiling yet and the bubbles are tiny, they are air coming out of solution from the water.
When water boils it forms water vapor. Being a gas it is far less dense than water and so floats.
Molecules of water -a microscopic explanation . At a macroscopic level, water vapour. A liquid boils when its vapour pressure equals the external pressure.
The water molecules split up upon boiling it. The two resulting components are oxigen (usually O2) and hydrogen (usually H2) which are both gases, forming the bubbles.
